text: And all the advice that you find out there on the internet is very general when it comes to product-market fit. You'll know it when you see it, you'll know it when you have it. It's not specific. And there's so many other startup topics where there is good content on the internet like hiring your first salesperson, running board meetings, stuff that is specific and tactical.
speaker: Todd Jackson
context: Lenny asks Todd why founders need a framework for finding product-market fit and why it's so important. Todd explains that product-market fit advice is typically vague and mysterious, unlike other startup topics that have specific, actionable guidance. He argues that while other areas like hiring or board meetings have detailed, tactical content available, product-market fit remains poorly explained despite being the most critical challenge for early-stage companies.
vocabulary_highlights: stuff that is specific and tactical
text_ko: 인터넷에 널린 조언들은 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)에 관해서는 거의 대부분 너무 일반적이에요. 한 번 보면 알게 되고, 실제로 갖고 있으면 알게 되긴 하는데 구체적인 건 아니죠. 반면에 첫 영업사원 채용이나 이사회 운영 같은 다른 스타트업 관련 주제들은 인터넷에 구체적이고 실무적인 좋은 콘텐츠가 정말 많아요.
text_zh: 网上关于产品市场匹配(product-market fit)的建议都特别泛泛而谈。什么"你有感觉的时候自然就知道了"，"找到了你就明白了"，一点都不具体。可是其他很多创业话题，网上都有很不错的干货内容，比如怎么招第一个销售，怎么开董事会，这些都很具体很实用。
text_es: Y todos los consejos que encuentras por ahí en internet sobre el encaje producto-mercado (product-market fit) son súper generales. Te dicen "lo vas a saber cuando lo veas", "te vas a dar cuenta cuando lo tengas". No es nada específico. Y hay tantos otros temas de startups donde sí hay buen contenido en internet, como contratar a tu primer vendedor, manejar juntas de consejo, cosas que sí son específicas y prácticas.

text: Finding product-market fit is the single most important thing that your startup does in the first three years, and it's just underexplored and it's just underexplained as a topic. So we felt this was a very important thing to do, something worth focusing on.
speaker: Todd Jackson
context: Todd is explaining why he and First Round Capital developed their product-market fit framework. He emphasizes that despite being the most critical milestone for startups in their early years, product-market fit lacks comprehensive, actionable guidance compared to other business topics. This knowledge gap motivated them to create a systematic approach to help founders navigate this crucial challenge.
text_ko: 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾는 건 스타트업이 처음 3년 동안 하는 일 중에서 가장 중요한 일이에요. 그런데 이 주제는 충분히 탐구되지도 않았고, 제대로 설명된 적도 별로 없어요. 그래서 저희는 이걸 꼭 다뤄야 할 중요한 주제로 보고 집중할 가치가 있다고 생각했어요.
text_zh: 找到产品市场匹配度(product-market fit)是你们创业公司头三年最重要的事儿，没有之一。但这个话题研究得太少了，也没人好好讲清楚过。所以我们觉得这事儿特别重要，值得花心思去做。
text_es: Lograr el ajuste producto-mercado (product-market fit) es lo más importante que puede hacer tu startup en los primeros tres años, y es un tema que está súper poco explorado y mal explicado. Por eso sentimos que era algo muy importante de hacer, algo en lo que valía la pena enfocarse.

text: Because if you find extreme product-market fit, the momentum just carries you, and the market pulls you along. And it's easy to know what to build because you're building the thing that your customers want and it's motivating as a team. It's easy to hire people, everything becomes easier if you find product-market fit, it is the thing that propels the company.
speaker: Todd Jackson
context: Lenny asks Todd to elaborate on why product-market fit is so critical for founders to focus on. Todd describes how achieving strong product-market fit creates a virtuous cycle where market forces work in the company's favor. He explains that when customers truly want your product, it simplifies decision-making across all business functions - from product development to hiring - because the market demand provides clear direction and momentum.
text_ko: 압도적인 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾으면 추진력이 저절로 따라와서 시장이 회사를 끌고 가요. 고객들이 진짜 원하는 걸 만드는 거니까 뭘 만들어야 할지도 명확하고, 팀도 훨씬 의욕이 생겨요. 채용도 쉬워지고, 모든 게 더 수월해져요. 제품-시장 적합성 자체가 회사를 앞으로 밀어주는 힘이에요.
text_zh: 因为一旦你找到了极佳的产品市场契合度(product-market fit)，那种势头就会推着你往前走，市场会拉着你跑。而且你很清楚该做什么产品，因为你在做的就是客户真正想要的东西，这对团队来说特别有动力。招人也变得容易，有了产品市场契合度，什么事都变简单了，这就是推动公司发展的核心动力。
text_es: Porque si logras un encaje producto-mercado (product-market fit) increíble, el impulso te lleva solo, y el mercado te jala. Y es súper fácil saber qué construir porque estás haciendo exactamente lo que tus clientes quieren, y eso motiva un montón al equipo. Es más fácil contratar gente, todo se vuelve más sencillo cuando encuentras ese encaje producto-mercado (product-market fit), es lo que realmente impulsa la empresa.

text: We can't guarantee success here. I just want to contextualize that finding extreme product-market fit is very, very hard. And what we are trying to do is increase your odds, increase the odds, reduce the role of luck, give you a framework and way of thinking about the things that you need to do.
speaker: Todd Jackson
context: Lenny asks Todd about the realistic benefits and outcomes founders can expect from following this product-market fit framework. Todd provides an honest assessment, emphasizing that no framework can guarantee success in what remains an extremely challenging endeavor. He positions their approach as a way to improve probability of success rather than a silver bullet, focusing on systematic thinking over relying purely on chance.
text_ko: 여기서 성공을 보장할 수는 없어요. 다만 극단적인 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)을 찾아내는 건 정말, 정말 어렵다는 맥락을 설명드리고 싶어요. 우리가 하려는 건 성공 확률을 높여드리고, 운의 역할을 줄여드리며, 해야 할 일들에 대해 생각할 수 있는 프레임워크(framework)와 사고방식(way of thinking)을 제공하는 거예요.
text_zh: 我们不能保证一定成功哈。我想先说清楚，要找到特别好的产品市场匹配(product-market fit)真的是超级难的事儿。我们现在要做的就是提高你们成功的概率，减少运气的成分，给你们一套框架和思路，让你们知道该怎么去做这些事情。
text_es: No podemos garantizar el éxito aquí. Solo quiero poner en contexto que lograr un product-market fit extremo es súper, súper difícil. Y lo que estamos tratando de hacer es aumentar tus probabilidades, mejorar las chances, reducir el papel de la suerte, darte un marco de trabajo y una forma de pensar sobre las cosas que necesitas hacer.

text: But the interesting thing is that you don't go for all three of them from the very beginning. And so product-market fit, it happens in the sequence of levels, it happens over multiple years. And for the best enterprise companies, I would say they tend to reach extreme product-market fit in roughly four to six years.
speaker: Todd Jackson
context: Todd is explaining his framework's three key dimensions of product-market fit: demand, satisfaction, and efficiency. He's clarifying that companies don't need to optimize all three dimensions simultaneously from day one. Instead, product-market fit develops progressively through distinct levels over several years, with the most successful enterprise companies typically achieving the highest level within four to six years of founding.
text_ko: 재미있는 건 처음부터 세 가지를 모두 한꺼번에 노리지는 않는다는 점이에요. 제품-시장 적합성(product-market fit)은 단계별로, 여러 해에 걸쳐 서서히 찾아와요. 저는 최고의 엔터프라이즈 기업들(enterprise companies)이 보통 대략 4~6년 정도에 아주 강한 제품-시장 적합성에 도달한다고 봐요.
text_zh: 但有意思的是，你不可能一开始就把这三个方面都搞定。所以产品市场匹配(product-market fit)嘛，它是分层次、分阶段来的，需要好几年时间。对于那些最牛的企业级公司来说，我觉得他们一般要花个四到六年左右才能达到极致的产品市场匹配(product-market fit)。
text_es: Pero lo interesante es que no vas por los tres desde el primer día. Entonces el product-market fit, pasa por niveles, en secuencia, lleva varios años. Y para las mejores empresas B2B, yo diría que tienden a alcanzar un product-market fit extremo en unos cuatro a seis años aproximadamente.

text: And the reason that she needed to get it is because we wanted to start selling Dropbox Paper into enterprise. And so she said to me, 'There's this pain out there, I think I can solve it, and I think there might be a revenue unlock.' And I was like, 'What do you mean by that?' And she was like, 'Well, I've got these first few customers or design partner, pseudo customers.'
speaker: Todd Jackson
context: Todd is sharing the origin story of Vanta as an example of level one product-market fit. He's describing how founder Christina Cacioppo discovered the compliance automation opportunity while working at Dropbox. Christina realized that SOC 2 certification was blocking enterprise sales deals, and she identified this as both a painful problem and a potential revenue unlock for her target customers who were trying to sell into Fortune 500 companies.
text_ko: 그녀가 이걸 꼭 가져와야 했던 이유는 우리가 Dropbox Paper를 기업에 판매하기 시작하고 싶었기 때문이에요. 그래서 그녀가 저한테 '이런 문제들이 있는데, 내가 해결할 수 있을 것 같고, 수익을 창출할 수 있는 기회가 있을 것 같아'라고 말했어요. 제가 '그게 무슨 뜻이에요?'라고 물어보니까, 그녀가 '음, 몇몇 초기 고객이나 디자인 파트너, 가짜 고객들이 있어'라고 했어요.
text_zh: 她之前需要拿到这个认证，是因为我们想把Dropbox Paper卖给企业客户。然后她就跟我说，"市场上有这个痛点，我觉得我能解决，而且我觉得这可能是个赚钱的机会。"我就问她，"你这话是什么意思？"她说，"我已经有了几个初期客户，或者说设计合作伙伴(design partner)，算是准客户吧。"
text_es: Y la razón por la que necesitaba conseguirlo es porque queríamos empezar a vender Dropbox Paper a empresas grandes. Entonces me dice: "Hay un problema ahí afuera, creo que lo puedo resolver, y pienso que podría generar ingresos nuevos (revenue unlock)." Y yo le digo: "¿A qué te refieres con eso?" Y me contesta: "Bueno, ya tengo estos primeros clientes o socios de diseño (design partners), como clientes potenciales."
